What it is

Why this practice matters for you now

Toby, youâ€™re in the stabilization phase â€” shedding feels heavy, but your scalp is still capable of growing baby hairs. Right now, your body needs steady fuel to repair from your ongoing health flare. A strong, proteinâ€‘based breakfast is your big domino: it stabilizes hormones, curbs stress on your system, and paves the way for regrowth once shedding finally eases. Early mornings are where you can tip momentum in your favor.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Within 60 minutes of waking, plan a breakfast with at least 25â€“30 g of protein.
  2. Choose simple options:
    • Omnivore: 3 scrambled eggs + avocado + side of smoked salmon.
    • Vegan: Tofu scramble with spinach + chickpea pancake or protein smoothie with pea protein.
  3. Add color: Â½ cup berries or leafy greens for antioxidants.

  • Early wins: More morning energy, fewer midâ€‘day sugar crashes, and steadier moods within a week.

week3.practice2_html:
What it is

â€œTweak Whatâ€™s on Your Plateâ€ is about adjusting your meals so your body has the steady supply of protein, healthy fats, and micronutrients it needs to support strong, resilient hair growth.

Why this practice matters for you now

Toby, youâ€™re in the stabilization phase: shedding is still high from your chronic illness flare but your scalp has already shown baby hairs, which is an encouraging sign. Right now, the fastest way to help your follicles hold onto new growth is to improve the fuel you give them day to day. Making small upgrades in protein and anti-inflammatory foods is your â€œbig dominoâ€ for nudging your body from shedding into repair mode.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Add one extra protein-rich meal daily (aim for 20â€“30 g: chicken, lentils, eggs, or Greek yogurt).
  2. Include a source of omega-3s 2â€“3 times this week (salmon, sardines, chia, or an algae oil supplement if preferred).
  3. Build plates with half vegetables, a quarter protein, a quarter whole grains or starchy veggies, plus healthy fats.
  4. Front-load your last main meal at least 2 hours before bed to avoid late-night digestion disrupting sleep.

What to look for

  • Early wins: Feeling more steady energy in the afternoons, fewer sugar cravings, and noticing less brittle texture when brushing or washing.
  • Watch-outs: You often eat your last meal right before bed â€” this can fragment sleep. Quick fix: shift it earlier by 30â€“45 minutes and notice your nights improve.
  • Consistency builds momentum â€” every balanced plate is a quiet signal of â€œsafetyâ€ to your follicles. One meal at a time, youâ€™re creating the environment for regrowth. ğŸŒ±
week3.practice3_html:
What it is

â€œEat More Good Fatsâ€ is about gently adding omegaâ€‘3 rich foods (like salmon, sardines, chia, or flax) to your meals, so your scalp gets the steady nourishment it needs for calmer shedding and stronger regrowth.

Why this practice matters for you now

Toby, youâ€™re in stabilization â€” shedding still feels high, but your follicles are already showing signs of life with those baby hairs. Because your chronic illness is still flaring, reducing quiet inflammation through omegaâ€‘3s is your single strongest lever. Think of it as calming the â€œbackground noiseâ€ that keeps your scalp stressed, helping you move toward steadier shedding before regrowth takes off in early spring.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Pick two days this week to add a palmâ€‘sized portion of fatty fish like salmon, mackerel, or sardines. If youâ€™re plantâ€‘based, use chia, ground flax, or hemp seeds daily.
  2. On mornings when you have time, stir a spoonful of ground flax into oatmeal or blend chia into a smoothie.
  3. Check labels if you use supplements: choose ones that are tested for freshness (to avoid rancid oils) and provide both EPA and DHA.
  4. Swap out one processed snack (chips, pastries) for a handful of walnuts or pumpkin seeds to nudge your balance toward healthier fats.

What to look for

  • Early wins: Less scalp itchiness or tightness; feeling subtly calmer in the evenings; digestion that feels smoother within 7â€“14 days.
  • Watch-outs: Because your last meal is very close to bedtime, pairing heavy fats late can disturb sleep. If you notice this, shift oily fish or seeds earlier in the day.
  • Consistency builds momentum â€” one thoughtful meal at a time is moving you closer to calmer shedding and stronger regrowth. ğŸŒ±

week3.week_summary_html:

That means cortisol stays higher, growth hormone release is blunted, and your follicles donâ€™t get the full repair signal at night. By tightening your sleep window, cutting off caffeine after lunch, and creating a windâ€‘down ritual, youâ€™re directly telling your system: â€œitâ€™s safe to pause the shedding cycle.â€
